title: Punishment for murder
description: Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder
description:
1. Whoever commits culpable homicide not amounting to murder shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine, if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing death, or of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death.
2. If the act is done with the knowledge that it is likely to cause death, but without any intention to cause death, or to cause such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, punishment may extend to ten years, or fine, or both.

title: Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property
description: Whoever cheats and thereby dishonestly induces the person deceived to deliver any property to any person, or to make, alter or destroy the whole or any part of a valuable security, or anything which is signed or sealed, and which is capable of being converted into a valuable security, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Punishment for rape
description: Whoever, except in the cases provided for by sub-section (2), commits rape, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than ten years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty
description: Whoever, being the husband or the relative of the husband of a woman, subjects such woman to cruelty shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to three years and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Attempt to murder
description: Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge, and under such circumstances that, if he by that act caused death, he would be guilty of murder, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.

title: Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt
description: Whoever, except in the case provided for by section 334, voluntarily causes hurt, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.

title: Punishment for theft
description: Whoever commits theft shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Punishment for criminal breach of trust
description: Whoever commits criminal breach of trust shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

title: Punishment for criminal intimidation
description: Whoever commits, the offence of criminal intimidation shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.

case_name: K.M. Nanavati v. State of Maharashtra
facts: Nanavati, a naval officer, shot his wife's lover Prem Ahuja. The main issue was whether it was murder or culpable homicide not amounting to murder due to grave and sudden provocation.
holding: The Supreme Court held that the provocation was not sudden and grave enough to reduce the offense from murder to culpable homicide not amounting to murder.
legal_principles: Test for grave and sudden provocation
ratio_decidendi: The test of 'sudden and grave provocation' is whether a reasonable man, belonging to the same class of society as the accused, placed in the situation in which the accused was placed would be so provoked as to lose his self-control.
significance: Last jury trial in India. Defined the law on grave and sudden provocation.

case_name: Vishaka & Ors v. State of Rajasthan & Ors
facts: Basic facts regarding workplace sexual harassment.
holding: Laid down guidelines to be followed by employers to prevent sexual harassment at workplace, known as Vishaka Guidelines.
significance: Paved the way for the Sexual Harassment of Women at Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013.

facts: Constitutionality of Narco-analysis, Polygraph and BRAIN mapping tests.
holding: Compulsory administration of these tests violates Article 20(3) and Article 21.
legal_principles: Right against self-incrimination includes right to maintain silence
ratio_decidendi: Involuntary administration of neuro-scientific tests violates the right against self-incrimination.

case_name: Mukesh & Anr v. State for NCT of Delhi & Ors (Nirbhaya case)
facts: Brutal gang rape and murder of a paramedic student in Delhi.
holding: Upheld the death sentence for the convicts.
ratio_decidendi: The aggravating circumstances outweighed the mitigating circumstances. The crime shocked the collective conscience of society.
significance: Led to stricter rape laws (Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 2013).

case_name: Shreya Singhal v. Union of India
facts: Challenge to the validity of Section 66A of the IT Act which criminalized offensive online speech.
issues: Freedom of speech and expression on internet
ratio_decidendi: Section 66A was vague and overbroad, having a chilling effect on free speech.
significance: Major victory for online free speech.
